THE NEWS-LETTER.

etry, no matter how large a library he may
have.
Two series of selections, of superior merit, I
ought also to mention. Ward's English Poets,
in four volumes, is the work of many minds.
The editor-in-chief, Mr. Humphrey Ward, secured the collaboration of several of the best
critics of the day. With their assistance he made
an anthology superior to any other that has
been made in English. The execution of the
work is, perhaps, superior to that of Crepet's
Lcs Poetes Francais, which furnished the
model. The volumes contain selections from
the English poets, from Chaucer to Tennyson.
Prefixed to the selections from each poet are
a short biographical sketch and a critical essay
by some one who was known to be a student of
the poet or of the period to which he belonged;
and prefixed to the first volume is Matthew Arnold's essay on Poetry. These volumes should
not be allowed to take the place of the complete
works of our greater poets, unless temporarily
as a stop-gap; but they may be extremely serviceable for the works of our lesser poets—as
Herrick, Prior, Collins, Blake, Landon
A similar work, though of less value, is
Craik's English Prose, which has recently been
completed in five volumes. It contains specimens of English prose from Wiclif to Stevenson.
In this short paper it is not possible to discuss the merits of various editions. Reasonably good editions of the works of all the
writers that I have named—the complete poetical works (not including their translations) of
the sixteen poets, copious selections from the
works of the nine prose writers, also a Golden
Treasury, the four volumes of Ward's English
Poets, and the five volumes of Craik's English
Prose—can be bought, I think, for about fifty
dollars. This is not a large expenditure to
spread over an undergraduate course of study,
especially when we remember that the investment may bring in a steady return for life.
Many men burn this amount of money every
year.
A choice library, not a large one, is what the

student needs. Why should a student spend
just this amount of money, or buy just the
books that I have named? No two private
libraries should be exactly alike; every library
should reflect the tastes and the pursuits of the
owner. Nor is it usually advisable for a student to buy books by the cubic foot or yard, to
be read at some time in the future; such purchases are for librarians. To be sure one
should never look askance at the offer of a tendollar bill to be expended for books ; but the
library that one has most affection for is that
which has been collected gradually, two or three
books at a time, as one had use for them, and
in which the books may indicate some sacrifice
or self-denial. What were the words of Erasmus? "I have given up my whole soul to Greek
learning, and as soon as I get any money, I
shall buy Greek books—and then I shall buy
sonic clothes." There spoke the true scholar.
In the same spirit—very unwisely, to be sure—
John Richard Green went without his dinner
for many days in order that he might complete
his set of the Acta Sanctorum.
My student readers have ere this perceived
that I am merely saying in print what year by
year I have said in season—I hope not out of
season—by voice. It has been a satisfaction to
me to know that during their undergraduate
course many students have laid the foundation
of a good library. It has been a yet greater satisfaction to learn that in cases not a few the
appetite for reading has grown by what it fed
on, and that the growth of the library has kept
even pace. For the period of undergraduate
study is merely an introduction to English literature ; and the joy of literary study is that it
is inexhaustible.
When Sir John Lubbock published his list of
"The Best Hundred Books" some of his readers
were so malicious as to raise doubts as to
whether he had himself read all the books
named in his list. Let me say very frankly, that
T have not read every page in every book that I
have named. Let me quote, in explanation, the
opening line of the most charming of Chaucer's
minor poems:

AN OPEN LETTER FROM THE DEAN.

To the Editor of The News Letter:
As the time for the class banquets approaches,
I ask your kind permission to remind the student body of the action taken by the authorities
of the University last spring.
It will be remembered that no little interruption of good order, and no little unfavorable
comment on the part of the public, were occasioned by the interference with these festivities last year. Properly informed persons understand that the disturbances were not due to
ill-will between the classes, or to any desire of
the participants to show disrespect toward the
authorities. It must be obvious, however, to all
who recall the events of last year that the evils
connected with this custom have become intolerable.
May I appeal to the good sense and good
feeling of all undergraduates in this matter?
The Trustees and the Faculty are far from
wishing to interfere with the pleasure of the
students; but it is for the interest of all to refrain from anything confessedly injurious to
the institution in which we have a common concern.

EDWARD H. GRIFFIN.
January 16, 1899.

preparations have been deferred until late in the
term ; but this year the clubs have been hard
at work since the first of October. Practice has
been constant, and the corridors of McCoy and
Hopkins Halls have resounded with college
glees and the thrum of banjos. The selection
and arrangement of pieces made for the instrumental clubs by Mr. Peters is very fortunate. "The Picaninnies" is a dainty little snatch
from Carryll's "Runaway Girl," that is now so
popular in New York, while the arrangement of
catchy airs from the operas, "Yankee Doodle
Dandy" and "The Telephone Girl," are sure
to be enthusiastically received. "Georgia Campmeeting" is so popular that it has grown to be
a bore, but Mill has put all of its inspiring
swing into his latest piece, "Whistling Rufus,"
that the Banjo Club will play. Beside these, a
number of other recent pieces will go to make
up the programme. The growth in membership of the clubs has been unusual, and those
who knew the Glee Club of old days will be
startled to find its ranks increased to 24 men,
among whom are many new men from the
Medical School, who have had valuable training on the Yale Glee Club. Darky melodies,
such as "Cotton Dolly," and selections from
the operas, such as the "Scare Crow Song,"
from De Koven's "Highwayman," are mingled
with the jovial songs so dear to the college men,
while the new medley of ditties of the day,
which Mr. Jungbluth and Mr. Fischer have
cleverly interwoven, is sure of a warm greeting.
With such clubs and such pieces it should be
unnecessary to urge all the University men to
extend their hearty support to these representatives of Johns Hopkins.

In this issue appears the first of a series of
articles, "Points on Athletics," prepared by
men well qualified by long experience on track
and field to treat the special subjects. W. H.
Maddren, who contributes the article in this
number, "Lacrosse for Beginners," played on
the famous -Crescent" team, and for two years
has been a stronghold on the 'Varsity. Beginners will find his article full of pointed and
practical suggestions. C. W. Ottley will in
the same helpful way give "Points on Training
for Long Distance Running"; Dr. Shattuck
will write on sprinting, and other articles on
ball playing, jumping, and weight-putting will
be included in the series.
This number of THE NEWS LETTER goes
into the hands of many who are not subscribers.
It is designed as a reminder that our subscription list is not nearly as large as it ought to be.
Many colleges, smaller than Hopkins, support
two papers. Not that we apprehend financial
failure. Happily, THE NEWS LETTER has always been able to pay its debts, but we feel
that this is not enough. We want very many
more readers and contributors. The paper will
become better and cheaper as these increase in
number. For the remainder of the year, which

includes nine of the seventeen issues, one of
them being the illustrated commencement number, the subscription rate will be seventy-five
cents. We hope to add many new names for
the second half-year.
A note from the Dean of the University,
printed in another part of this number, calls attention to a law of the faculty in regard to
class banquets and hazing. This is the only
law of its kind at Hopkins. It used to be customary to point out with considerable pride the
fact that the University had no rules as to the
conduct of its students. Hazing of candidates
and kidnapping of would-be banqueters went
on in a quiet way, and, apparently, neither the
institution nor the students were the worse for
it. Last year the conditions were peculiar.
The affairs of the University were before the
public in a special degree, and it was very easy
for an over-zealous reporter to magnify a perfectly innocent prank into an act of ruffianism.
Moreover, at the time of the junior banquet, the
exigencies of the occasion seemed to demand a
general cut for two days, and this was undesirable at any time. The matter seemed so important that the authorities departed from the tradition of former years, and made a special rule
on the subject. It seems unfortunate that this
was necessary. It would be still more unfortunate if it should be necessary to enforce the
law. Yet, in case of its violation, the University
would be subjected to criticism all the more
severe if the rule were not carried into effect.
The duty of the undergraduates is plain.
The seniors will dine undisturbed, as usual,
with as much dignity as they can summon.
The juniors and freshmen should do the same.
The Dean was right in saying that there is no
between the classes. There is, howreal
ever, a keen rivalry, and there is no reason why
this should not find expression in organized
contests. With the difficulties of interference
removed, it will be possible to have the banquets
more generally attended! And what is lost in
other respects will be made up in increased
.class spirit.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
AFFAIRS OF A FORTNIGHT.

"The Feed" on the evening of the 12th attracted some two hundred hungry sons of Hopkins—faculty, alumni and students. Members
of the faculty present did their best to "look
pleasant," and though college spirit did not run
mad, everybody went away happy. Fewer
alumni turned up than last year—a matter for
regret, since these occasions are primarily projected to keep the old-timers in touch with
'Varsity athletics. The .formidably built, but
pleasantly disposed, bull-dog that strayed in for
the evening did a great deal to give snap to the
Programme. He patronized the President, the
Dean and Professor Remsen, then took charge
of the freshman, the living graphophone, who
essayed to out-Sousa Sousa. The dog objected. We can understand his feelings. The
"feed" itself was dimmed in comparison with
the set-out of last year, in which the broiled
oyster and croquette figured pleasantly. There
was a good deal of the "cane rush" in the
service ; next year's committee will do well
to puzzle out a better way of "feeding the
animals," for the " Feed in the Cage" has
come to stay.

The University is again happily identified
with municipal interests through the election of
President Gilman to the presidency of the Municipal Art Society. The organization of the society was brought about last week, at a meeting
of representative men of the city. The society
is incorporated, and sets out to provide adequate sculptural and pictorial decorations and
ornaments for public buildings, streets and
open spaces in Baltimore, and to help generally to beautify the city. Dr. Gilman indicated that the chief aim of the society should
be to mould public opinion and to see that
efforts a r e put forth for improvement.
Though the society was incorporated for "ornamental purposes," the newly-elected president evidently does not intend to have the conventional construction placed on the term, and

aggressively pointed,outthat an immediate interest and opportunity was to be found in the
mural decoration of the new courthouse.
EXCHANGES.

The Christmas Kalends (Woman's College,
Baltimore), is before us. There is mistletoe
and holly and a frosty snow scene on the special
Christmas cover. How like the girls to have
mistletoe. Following a very entertaining leader, "Social Life at an English College," fragrant with the aroma of tea, chocolate and
cocoa, is the best thing in the book—a lovely
article from the pearl pen of a soulful senior
on "Music in Education," in which there is a
great deal of the "intangible" and "immaterial,"
refulgent with "a new sunshine which floods
and sweetens." I had begun to fear that the
sweet girl-graduate's commencement essay was
on the wane; but The Kalends is doing good
work in preserving for us some of those oldtime, heart-stirring, poetic effusions which our
grandmothers wrote in the balmy days of June.
" The Little Chorister, and Others," are
Christmas sketches for which I wish I had
These
saved some of my best adjectives.
nursery,
any
for
enough
sketches, wholesome
are full of the tenderest sentiment. The "drooping willows," "the crystal ether," the joyous
chimes," the listening stars,""the unfathomable night" and "hearts too full for utterance"
all are delicate touches. I do not wonder that
our dreamy Nell" and the other children
sat up with "clear old grandma" to hear those
stories until the inevitable "old clock on the
stairs"struck eleven. Children in their "teens"
ought to have been in bed long before that.
However, this was Christmas night.
That the college girls think The Kalends
is just about right is evidenced in the fact
that 113 out of 275 matriculates subscribe
and pay for their paper. I don't blame
the editors and the four business managers
for being "proud of our Kalends." The
162 girls who don't cash up ought to be
ashamed of themselves.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
POINTS ON ATHLETICS.
Lacrosse For Beginners.

It seems most appropriate to me at this time
to address my remarks to those who are taking
their first steps in lacrosse, in the hope that
some points which worried me when I was a
beginner may be made easier.
It is not my purpose to extol the merits of
the game, either as an all-round developer, or
as a pastime, partly because it needs no praise
of mine, and then because I am already considered a crank on the subject.
Lacrosse is essentially a game of common
sense. In it, to a greater degree than in any
other sport that I know of, it is possible to use
your head; and the man who carefully thinks
over and understands each play is the man who
in the end will be master of the game. If during practice, a player gets the ball away from
you, try to understand just how he managed to
do it, and then think out some way of combatting that play the next time it occurs. If you
do this, it will be an incredibly short time before you begin to be a "heady" player—that
greatest of all blessings to a team.
Almost any man, with practice, can become
proficient; so do not get easily discouraged.
The first few days, when you are in that chaotic
state where every ball that comes in your direction seems as if shot from a cannon, and just as
impossible to catch, and when to try to "pick
up" seems an utterly useless effort, perseverance alone is necessary to success, and soon
both catching and picking up will be the most
natural thing in the world.
And now let me urge you all to begin right.
It is hard to unlearn. Don't try to decide at first
whether you prefer to play attack or defense,
for the preliminary is the same, and that is to
learn to be master of your stick. Get accustomed to catching cleanly, no matter where the
ball cames to you, right or left, high in the
air or bouncing along the ground ; get control of it in your stick, and don't throw
until you do ; know it is there, and don't have

to look to see. Lacrosse games are won often
by one side because they are half a second
quicker than the other, and you must be determining before the ball reaches you just what
you are going to do with it; get used from
the very first to saving the half second you
would waste if you waited to get the ball before
making up your mind. But here let me warn
you of one of the greatest temptations of a
new player: To get rid of the ball after a pretty
catch as quickly as posssible without any idea
as to where it is going. Better by far lose the
ball by holding too long than throw it without
purpose. Think as quickly as you can, but
always think.
And when you are to go on the field to play
the game for the first time, find out exactly
what you are expected to do, and then put
your whole soul into the matter, and do it with
all your might. Watch the ball every moment.
Know just what is going on around you, and
note where your opponents and those of your
own side are; when the ball comes your way
start quickly. Get right after it as fast as you
can; if you get a start of a yard on your man,
it means you get the ball, and that may mean
the game. Play the ball always in preference
to playing the man.
Too many precepts are as bad as too few.
You won't remember half, possibly only one
point I have suggested ; but I hope that for
your own good, for the team's good, and for
the good of athletics at Johns Hopkins you will
remember that your head was given to you to
use, and most of all, perhaps, while playing
lacrosse.

At a meeting of the lacrosse team last week
Captain Robinson resigned, stating that he was
not living in the city now, and could not devote the necessary time required to develop
as good a team as Hopkins is capable of putting
on the field. The team was sorry to see Mr.
Robinson take this step, and a Vote of thanks
was extended to him, showing their appreciation of the efficient way in which he captained
last year's team to victory.
Thomas Fitzgerald, Jr., was elected to succeed Robinson. He is thought by everyone to
be the most capable man for the position and
there is every reason to believe that Hopkins
will be proud of her team during the coming
year.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY NEWS.
Frank J. Clunet, '98, and C. F. Diggs, 'cm,
have left the University to enter business life.
The bust of General Lee, which occupies a
prominent position in the Donovan Room was
recently decorated with a wreath, by the Daughters of the Confederacy.
The twenty-seventh Annual Tri-State Convention of the Y. M. C. A. will be held at Cumberland early in February. Delegates from the
University Association will attend.
Classes from the Senate and House are having special work under the direction of Dr. Lee,
in preparation for the public debate, which will
be held in March.

The competitive examinations for the fellowships of the American School of Classical
Studies, at Athens, will be held this year in
March. These fellowships yield $600 each.
The Hoppin Fellowship, open to women only,
yields Sim), and is assigned without examination.
The senior dinner will be held at the Mt.
Vernon Hotel, Monday evening, February 6.
Mr. Walter M. Krager will be toastmaster.
Toasts will be responded to: The Class of '99,
John C. French; The University, R. Harold
Grimes; The Ladies, Joshua Levering, Jr.;
Athletics, George W. Knapp, Jr.; Fellow Senators, Leon Joyner. The arrangements are in
charge of a committee, of which George L.
Taneyhill, Jr., is chairman.

During the coming month three important
courses of lectures will be given. Dr. Mitchell
Carroll, who received his Ph. D. here some
years ago, and who has been lecturing at the
University during the winter, will deliver a
course of eight lectures on the "History of
Greek Sculpture." Dr. Frederick M. Warren,
of Adelbert College, began on Wednesday his

THE NEWS-LETTER.

etry, no matter how large a library he may
have.
Two series of selections, of superior merit, I
ought also to mention. Ward's English Poets,
in four volumes, is the work of many minds.
The editor-in-chief, Mr. Humphrey Ward, secured the collaboration of several of the best
critics of the day. With their assistance he made
an anthology superior to any other that has
been made in English. The execution of the
work is, perhaps, superior to that of Crepet's
Lcs Poetes Francais, which furnished the
model. The volumes contain selections from
the English poets, from Chaucer to Tennyson.
Prefixed to the selections from each poet are
a short biographical sketch and a critical essay
by some one who was known to be a student of
the poet or of the period to which he belonged;
and prefixed to the first volume is Matthew Arnold's essay on Poetry. These volumes should
not be allowed to take the place of the complete
works of our greater poets, unless temporarily
as a stop-gap; but they may be extremely serviceable for the works of our lesser poets—as
Herrick, Prior, Collins, Blake, Landon
A similar work, though of less value, is
Craik's English Prose, which has recently been
completed in five volumes. It contains specimens of English prose from Wiclif to Stevenson.
In this short paper it is not possible to discuss the merits of various editions. Reasonably good editions of the works of all the
writers that I have named—the complete poetical works (not including their translations) of
the sixteen poets, copious selections from the
works of the nine prose writers, also a Golden
Treasury, the four volumes of Ward's English
Poets, and the five volumes of Craik's English
Prose—can be bought, I think, for about fifty
dollars. This is not a large expenditure to
spread over an undergraduate course of study,
especially when we remember that the investment may bring in a steady return for life.
Many men burn this amount of money every
year.
A choice library, not a large one, is what the

student needs. Why should a student spend
just this amount of money, or buy just the
books that I have named? No two private
libraries should be exactly alike; every library
should reflect the tastes and the pursuits of the
owner. Nor is it usually advisable for a student to buy books by the cubic foot or yard, to
be read at some time in the future; such purchases are for librarians. To be sure one
should never look askance at the offer of a tendollar bill to be expended for books ; but the
library that one has most affection for is that
which has been collected gradually, two or three
books at a time, as one had use for them, and
in which the books may indicate some sacrifice
or self-denial. What were the words of Erasmus? "I have given up my whole soul to Greek
learning, and as soon as I get any money, I
shall buy Greek books—and then I shall buy
sonic clothes." There spoke the true scholar.
In the same spirit—very unwisely, to be sure—
John Richard Green went without his dinner
for many days in order that he might complete
his set of the Acta Sanctorum.
My student readers have ere this perceived
that I am merely saying in print what year by
year I have said in season—I hope not out of
season—by voice. It has been a satisfaction to
me to know that during their undergraduate
course many students have laid the foundation
of a good library. It has been a yet greater satisfaction to learn that in cases not a few the
appetite for reading has grown by what it fed
on, and that the growth of the library has kept
even pace. For the period of undergraduate
study is merely an introduction to English literature ; and the joy of literary study is that it
is inexhaustible.
When Sir John Lubbock published his list of
"The Best Hundred Books" some of his readers
were so malicious as to raise doubts as to
whether he had himself read all the books
named in his list. Let me say very frankly, that
T have not read every page in every book that I
have named. Let me quote, in explanation, the
opening line of the most charming of Chaucer's
minor poems:

AN OPEN LETTER FROM THE DEAN.

To the Editor of The News Letter:
As the time for the class banquets approaches,
I ask your kind permission to remind the student body of the action taken by the authorities
of the University last spring.
It will be remembered that no little interruption of good order, and no little unfavorable
comment on the part of the public, were occasioned by the interference with these festivities last year. Properly informed persons understand that the disturbances were not due to
ill-will between the classes, or to any desire of
the participants to show disrespect toward the
authorities. It must be obvious, however, to all
who recall the events of last year that the evils
connected with this custom have become intolerable.
May I appeal to the good sense and good
feeling of all undergraduates in this matter?
The Trustees and the Faculty are far from
wishing to interfere with the pleasure of the
students; but it is for the interest of all to refrain from anything confessedly injurious to
the institution in which we have a common concern.

EDWARD H. GRIFFIN.
January 16, 1899.

With such clubs and such pieces it should be
unnecessary to urge all the University men to
extend their hearty support to these representatives of Johns Hopkins.

In this issue appears the first of a series of
articles, "Points on Athletics," prepared by
men well qualified by long experience on track
and field to treat the special subjects. W. H.
Maddren, who contributes the article in this
number, "Lacrosse for Beginners," played on
the famous -Crescent" team, and for two years
has been a stronghold on the 'Varsity. Beginners will find his article full of pointed and
practical suggestions. C. W. Ottley will in
the same helpful way give "Points on Training
for Long Distance Running"; Dr. Shattuck
will write on sprinting, and other articles on
ball playing, jumping, and weight-putting will
be included in the series.
This number of THE NEWS LETTER goes
into the hands of many who are not subscribers.
It is designed as a reminder that our subscription list is not nearly as large as it ought to be.
Many colleges, smaller than Hopkins, support
two papers. Not that we apprehend financial
failure. Happily, THE NEWS LETTER has always been able to pay its debts, but we feel
that this is not enough. We want very many
more readers and contributors. The paper will
become better and cheaper as these increase in
number. For the remainder of the year, which

includes nine of the seventeen issues, one of
them being the illustrated commencement number, the subscription rate will be seventy-five
cents. We hope to add many new names for
the second half-year.
A note from the Dean of the University,
printed in another part of this number, calls attention to a law of the faculty in regard to
class banquets and hazing. This is the only
law of its kind at Hopkins. It used to be customary to point out with considerable pride the
fact that the University had no rules as to the
conduct of its students. Hazing of candidates
and kidnapping of would-be banqueters went
on in a quiet way, and, apparently, neither the
institution nor the students were the worse for
it. Last year the conditions were peculiar.
The affairs of the University were before the
public in a special degree, and it was very easy
for an over-zealous reporter to magnify a perfectly innocent prank into an act of ruffianism.
Moreover, at the time of the junior banquet, the
exigencies of the occasion seemed to demand a
general cut for two days, and this was undesirable at any time. The matter seemed so important that the authorities departed from the tradition of former years, and made a special rule
on the subject. It seems unfortunate that this
was necessary. It would be still more unfortunate if it should be necessary to enforce the
law. Yet, in case of its violation, the University
would be subjected to criticism all the more
severe if the rule were not carried into effect.
The duty of the undergraduates is plain.
The seniors will dine undisturbed, as usual,
with as much dignity as they can summon.
The juniors and freshmen should do the same.
The Dean was right in saying that there is no
between the classes. There is, howreal
ever, a keen rivalry, and there is no reason why
this should not find expression in organized
contests. With the difficulties of interference
removed, it will be possible to have the banquets
more generally attended! And what is lost in
other respects will be made up in increased
.class spirit.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
AFFAIRS OF A FORTNIGHT.

"The Feed" on the evening of the 12th attracted some two hundred hungry sons of Hopkins—faculty, alumni and students. Members
of the faculty present did their best to "look
pleasant," and though college spirit did not run
mad, everybody went away happy. Fewer
alumni turned up than last year—a matter for
regret, since these occasions are primarily projected to keep the old-timers in touch with
'Varsity athletics. The .formidably built, but
pleasantly disposed, bull-dog that strayed in for
the evening did a great deal to give snap to the
Programme. He patronized the President, the
Dean and Professor Remsen, then took charge
of the freshman, the living graphophone, who
essayed to out-Sousa Sousa. The dog objected. We can understand his feelings. The
"feed" itself was dimmed in comparison with
the set-out of last year, in which the broiled
oyster and croquette figured pleasantly. There
was a good deal of the "cane rush" in the
service ; next year's committee will do well
to puzzle out a better way of "feeding the
animals," for the " Feed in the Cage" has
come to stay.

The University is again happily identified
with municipal interests through the election of
President Gilman to the presidency of the Municipal Art Society. The organization of the society was brought about last week, at a meeting
of representative men of the city. The society
is incorporated, and sets out to provide adequate sculptural and pictorial decorations and
ornaments for public buildings, streets and
open spaces in Baltimore, and to help generally to beautify the city. Dr. Gilman indicated that the chief aim of the society should
be to mould public opinion and to see that
efforts a r e put forth for improvement.
Though the society was incorporated for "ornamental purposes," the newly-elected president evidently does not intend to have the conventional construction placed on the term, and

aggressively pointed,outthat an immediate interest and opportunity was to be found in the
mural decoration of the new courthouse.

sweet girl-graduate's commencement essay was
on the wane; but The Kalends is doing good
work in preserving for us some of those oldtime, heart-stirring, poetic effusions which our
grandmothers wrote in the balmy days of June.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
POINTS ON ATHLETICS.
Lacrosse For Beginners.

It seems most appropriate to me at this time
to address my remarks to those who are taking
their first steps in lacrosse, in the hope that
some points which worried me when I was a
beginner may be made easier.
It is not my purpose to extol the merits of
the game, either as an all-round developer, or
as a pastime, partly because it needs no praise
of mine, and then because I am already considered a crank on the subject.
Lacrosse is essentially a game of common
sense. In it, to a greater degree than in any
other sport that I know of, it is possible to use
your head; and the man who carefully thinks
over and understands each play is the man who
in the end will be master of the game. If during practice, a player gets the ball away from
you, try to understand just how he managed to
do it, and then think out some way of combatting that play the next time it occurs. If you
do this, it will be an incredibly short time before you begin to be a "heady" player—that
greatest of all blessings to a team.
Almost any man, with practice, can become
proficient; so do not get easily discouraged.
The first few days, when you are in that chaotic
state where every ball that comes in your direction seems as if shot from a cannon, and just as
impossible to catch, and when to try to "pick
up" seems an utterly useless effort, perseverance alone is necessary to success, and soon
both catching and picking up will be the most
natural thing in the world.
And now let me urge you all to begin right.
It is hard to unlearn. Don't try to decide at first
whether you prefer to play attack or defense,
for the preliminary is the same, and that is to
learn to be master of your stick. Get accustomed to catching cleanly, no matter where the
ball cames to you, right or left, high in the
air or bouncing along the ground ; get control of it in your stick, and don't throw
until you do ; know it is there, and don't have

to look to see. Lacrosse games are won often
by one side because they are half a second
quicker than the other, and you must be determining before the ball reaches you just what
you are going to do with it; get used from
the very first to saving the half second you
would waste if you waited to get the ball before
making up your mind. But here let me warn
you of one of the greatest temptations of a
new player: To get rid of the ball after a pretty
catch as quickly as posssible without any idea
as to where it is going. Better by far lose the
ball by holding too long than throw it without
purpose. Think as quickly as you can, but
always think.
And when you are to go on the field to play
the game for the first time, find out exactly
what you are expected to do, and then put
your whole soul into the matter, and do it with
all your might. Watch the ball every moment.
Know just what is going on around you, and
note where your opponents and those of your
own side are; when the ball comes your way
start quickly. Get right after it as fast as you
can; if you get a start of a yard on your man,
it means you get the ball, and that may mean
the game. Play the ball always in preference
to playing the man.
Too many precepts are as bad as too few.
You won't remember half, possibly only one
point I have suggested ; but I hope that for
your own good, for the team's good, and for
the good of athletics at Johns Hopkins you will
remember that your head was given to you to
use, and most of all, perhaps, while playing
lacrosse.
W. H. MADDREN.
